article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Verbal Aggression: Understanding the Psychological Antecedents and Social Consequences

abstract.p: In an online survey study (n = 275), several demographic and personality variables were used to predict scores on the Rudeness Scale, a new measure of the propensity to verbally abuse strangers. The results of multiple regression analyses revealed a number of significant main effects. These effects revealed that the people in the authors’ sample who reported the greatest propensity to verbally abuse strangers were Hispanic/Latino or Black individuals who scored low in adherence to the standards of conventional morality but high in ego defensiveness (unwillingness to accept criticism or correction from others) and affect intensity for anger and frustration. The authors’ interpretation of the findings combines insights derived from Swann’s self-verification theory, contrasting views of ego defensiveness, and Larsen et al.’s work on affect intensity with a dispositional view of verbal rudeness that emphasizes its use as a weapon in interpersonal struggles for power, status, and “face.”

body.p: Rudeness is a disturbing fact of human life―a fact to which virtually no one is immune. Even Prince Charles and Camilla were the targets of rude behavior when a group of student protesters, angry at a proposed tuition increase, attacked the royal couple’s car “with sticks, fists and bottles and chanted ‘Off with their heads’ before the vehicle pushed its way through the crowd and drove off” (Lawless, 2010).

Fortunately, such acts of intentional and targeted rudeness appear to be relatively infrequent. According to Smith, Phillips, and King’s (2010) study of more than 500 rudeness incidents reported by an equally large sample of Australian respondents, most incidents of rudeness are the accidental consequence of a large flow of people trying to pass through the same area at the same time, whether in cars or on foot. For example, “People who pushed in front of me” made up fully 25% of all reported events (Smith et al., 2010, p. 24), and related categories such as “blocked my way,” “bumped into me,” “invaded my personal space,” “swerved in front of me,” and so on, collectively accounted for another 36%―for a total of 61% altogether (p. 25). In general, these events “did not seem to be deliberate, but rather to result from crowding, insensitivity and mixed trajectories and speeds” (p. 196).

In contrast, acts of verbal rudeness, though much less frequent by comparison, are typically both intentional and personally directed. In Smith et al.’s (2010) study, four categories of verbal rudeness accounted for a total of 20% of all events reported: swearing (11.3%), screaming, screeching, or shouting (5.6%), prejudicial comments (2.2%), and sexual remarks (0.9%). It is the more intentional and personally directed act of verbal rudeness, also known as verbal abuse, that is the topic of the present article.

sec.title: How Serious a Problem Is Verbal Rudeness?
sec.p: The data reported by Smith et al. (2010) suggest that people who are the targets of another person’s verbal abuse often feel angry and disgusted, particularly in the immediate aftermath of the encounter. In nearly all cases, however, these feelings quickly fade.

disp-quote.p: Interactions with the rude stranger tended to be brief. Efforts to remonstrate . . . were uncommon. Very few events escalated into ongoing conflicts. For the most part people just wanted to leave the situation or to let it drop. (Smith et al., 2010, p. 197)

sec.p: On the other hand, if the rude stranger represents a specific company or place of business, one’s negative reactions to that person might also translate into a decision to stop doing business with the establishment in question (Johnson & Indvik, 2001a, 2001b). This decision, when made by an increasingly large number of customers, can have a pronounced impact on the company’s or vendor’s bottom line. And if verbal abuse becomes a regular occurrence in established work relationships, such as those between managers and employees, male and female coworkers, and so on, it can eventually lead to more serious acts, such as open conflict, workplace violence, and sexual harassment (Johnson & Indvik, 2001a, 2001b).1 Similarly, recurring acts of verbal abuse in the context of personal relationships have the potential to destroy a child’s self-esteem, poison a friendship, and wreck a marriage.

sec.title: How Can We Account for Acts of Verbal Rudeness?
Verbal rudeness as accidental
sec.p: Smith et al. (2010) have argued that most acts of physical rudeness (pushing, bumping, blocking, etc.) are both accidental and situational, being the unintended consequence of “crowding, insensitivity and mixed trajectories and speeds” (p. 196). At least some incidents of (perceived) verbal rudeness are accidental as well. These would be described by Goffman (1974) as incidental misframings―cases in which one person is offended by a second person’s apparently rude (but, in regard to the first person, not intentionally rude) choice of words. For example, many international students are offended when they are referred to by Americans as “Orientals,” a term they regard as both pejorative and rude. This so-called offense is often accidental and unintended, however, because many American speakers simply do not know that the term Orientals has this negative connotation and that they should use the term Asians instead. A different type of incidental misframing occurs when an individual takes personally an insult that was intended for someone else. For example, when a person in a passing car shouts “Hey, asshole!” one should take the time to rule out other potential targets of this epithet before concluding that it was directed at oneself.

sec.title: Verbal rudeness as dispositional
sec.p: As we have noted, Smith et al.’s (2010) data suggest that most cases of verbal rudeness are not accidental; they are intentional and personally directed instead. Many of these intentional instances of verbal abuse probably have more to do with the perpetrator than with the victim. The prototypic example is provided by people who routinely use verbal abuse as a way to bully and intimidate others. For individuals in this category, the propensity to bully others has acquired the status of an enduring disposition. Verbal bullying may either be their preferred mode of expressing this disposition or it may serve to augment the physical bullying that these individuals often perpetrate (Lowenstein, 1977, 1994). In either case, the verbal bully may require little or no provocation. Even innocent bystanders may be the target of the verbal bully’s attacks, particularly if they are negatively stigmatized (e.g., as gay, obese, clumsy, learning-disabled, or having minority group status) and if they appear to be weak, easily intimidated, and unlikely to retaliate (cf. Fox & Farrow, 2009; Swearer, Turner, Givens, & Pollack, 2008; Tharinger, 2008; Warwick, Aggleton, & Douglas, 2001).

The issue of provocation is a tricky one, however, because the perception of provocation as a justified “cause” of verbal bullying exists primarily in the mind of the perpetrator. Inveterate bullies appear to be biased to perceive provocation even in situations in which other people do not. Indeed, a “thin-skinned” hypersensitivity to perceived slights, criticisms, challenges, and provocations has been observed both in child bullies (Dodge & Coie, 1987; Schwartz & Dodge, 1998) and in maritally aggressive/abusive husbands (Robillard & Noller, 2011; Schweinle & Ickes, 2007; Schweinle, Ickes, & Bernstein, 2002).

sec.title: Verbal rudeness as a weapon in interpersonal struggles for power and “face.”
sec.p: Since the publication of Brown and Levinson’s (1987) theory of politeness/impoliteness in language use, it has been increasingly recognized (cf. Bousfield & Locher, 2008; Limberg, 2009) that verbal rudeness, when used intentionally and strategically, can be a powerful weapon in interpersonal struggles for power, status, and “face.”2

Of particular interest to us are cases in which Person A challenges, and thereby threatens, the “face”―and, implicitly, the status and power―of Person B (see Limberg, 2009). This act in itself is inherently rude, or at least impolite, in that its goal is to criticize, correct, or otherwise humble Person B by pressuring Person B to yield ground, to apologize, to stand corrected, to acknowledge fault or weakness, and so on. If Person B succumbs to this pressure, Person A stands to achieve a status gain (get “one-up”), whereas Person B stands to experience a status loss (get “one-down”). However, because this act may well be perceived by Person B as an attack on B’s power, status, and “face,” Person A may be careful to reserve this act only for occasions in which B can be “justifiably” criticized because B’s current behavior fails to meet a conventional standard of correct or appropriate behavior.

Some examples of this type of interpersonal encounter are provided in Appendix A; these incidents are used as the item content of the present authors’ Rudeness Scale (RS). As the reader can see, the threat to Person B’s status is oblique, rather than direct, in most of these incidents. At the surface level, A’s communication to B is presented as a seemingly well-intentioned bid to get B to respond in a way that simultaneously (a) acknowledges fault, (b) makes a gesture toward “repairing” it, and (c) respects Person A (i.e., preserves Person A’s “face”) for issuing the challenge. There is always the risk, however, that Person B will not accept Person A’s challenge as a well-intentioned opportunity to repair the situation while permitting the mutual preservation of “face,” but will instead view it as A’s attempt to get one-up by putting B in his or her place, that is, one-down.

From B’s perspective, the choice is to accept A’s bid at face value, along with the humbling―or worse yet, the humiliation―that goes with it, or to reject A’s bid and assert B’s claim to unimpugned status. This counterresponse by B of rejecting A’s bid can vary greatly along a dimension of diplomacy. At one extreme, A’s bid can be deflected by B in such a subtle and politely phrased way that A is left nonplussed. At the other extreme, A’s bid can be rejected by B in such a rude and “in-your-face” way that A is forced to confront B’s naked hostility and obvious willingness to escalate the unpleasantness of the encounter.

Thus, verbal rudeness is, for B, a tool (or, more bluntly, a weapon) that B can use to strip away the veneer of social politeness from the encounter and re-present it to A as a starkly defined contest for status, power, and “face.” More specifically, verbal rudeness is a countermove that simultaneously lays bare what B perceives to be an underlying status conflict with A and escalates that conflict dramatically. Stated in its crudest terms, B’s countermove of in-your-face rudeness communicates to A: “You want me to eat shit? No, you eat shit instead!” Indeed, B’s rude attack on A’s “face” is so crude, immediate, intense, and uncompromising that A’s options are either to back off and retreat from the encounter or to remain engaged and risk experiencing an even more hostile response from B. Given these two unpleasant options, it is noteworthy that, according to Smith et al.’s (2010) Australian data, most people in the role of Person A choose to withdraw from the encounter as quickly as possible (a move in which they clearly lose some “face”), rather than to escalate it further and risk an even greater loss of “face.”

sec.title: Who Is Most Likely to Display Verbal Rudeness?
sec.p: In the present investigation, we combined a focus on rudeness as dispositional with a focus on rudeness as instrumental in the struggle for power and “face.” More specifically, we designed this study to explore individual differences in the propensity to verbally abuse hypothetical strangers who adopt the role of Person A in regard to oneself (Person B).3 Because these kinds of encounters tend to precipitate widely varying reactions in individuals who occupy the Person B role (be polite, cede some “face,” and de-escalate the unpleasantness, or be rude, cede nothing, and dramatically escalate the unpleasantness), it should be possible to capture these widely varying reactions in respondents’ scores on the RS that we developed (see Appendix A).

Our goal in the present study was to begin to explore the personal characteristics of individuals who report a propensity to verbally abuse strangers in the kinds of situations just described. In the service of this goal, we conducted an online survey study in which our respondents were asked to provide some basic demographic information and then complete six personality measures that we thought might predict their scores on our RS (the last measure to appear on the online survey).

sec.title: Potential demographic predictors
sec.p: The demographic predictors we included in the survey were age, gender, race/ethnicity, and socioeconomic status (SES). Despite the stereotypic image that holds that rude people are likely to be young, working class, minority males, only gender (i.e., being male vs. female) emerged as a consistent predictor of rude behavior in Smith et al.’s (2010) study of a large Australian sample. Age, race/ethnicity, and SES did not.

sec.title: Potential personality predictors
sec.p: The personality predictors we included in the survey were social desirability, aggression/hostility, impulsivity, adherence to conventional morality, ego defensiveness (i.e., unwillingness to accept criticism), and affect intensity for aggression and frustration (AIAF). The specific measures used to assess each of these constructs are described in the “Method” section.

Why did we choose this set of personality predictors? Two of them were suggested by Lynne Truss’s (2005) mostly satirical but also somewhat speculative book about rudeness, Talk to the Hand. In this book, Truss characterized rude people as those who have little or no respect for conventional morality and manners (i.e., those who should score low in adherence to conventional morality) and “who simply will not stand to be corrected in any way” (i.e., those who should score high in thin-skinned ego defensiveness). Our own theoretical speculations further suggested that rude people are easily and intensely angered by even small challenges and presumed “provocations,” so we included measures of aggression/hostility, impulsivity, and AIAF as well. Finally, because admitting to rude behavior is a socially undesirable thing to do, we decided to include a brief measure of social desirability as a final possible predictor or covariate.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The participants were 275 undergraduate students who were enrolled in introductory psychology courses at the University of Texas–Arlington. The sample included 210 females, 64 males, and 1 student who declined to answer the question involving gender. The participants’ ages ranged from 17 to 50 years (median age = 20 years), and their racial/ethnic composition was 38.9% White/Anglo-American, 21.1% Hispanic/Latino, 17.3% Black/African American, 16% Asian, 0.4% Native American/Alaskan Native, 5.5% Other/Multicultural, and 1.1% who declined to answer the question on race/ethnicity.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: All the participants were recruited via the internet through the Psychology Department’s experiment tracking software system, SONA (Fidler, 1997). Those participants who chose to participate in the present study were directed to our survey on the SurveyMonkey website. They began by reading an online consent document and clicking the “YES” response to acknowledge their informed consent to its terms.

All respondents received experimental participation credit for completing the online survey. The survey was programmed so that all measures had to be answered in the order presented; the respondents were unable to view upcoming measures or to return to change their answers to previous ones. The respondents were free to decline to answer any question and could discontinue their participation at any time. All procedures used in this study were approved by the Institutional Review Board of the University of Texas–Arlington.

sec.title: Online Survey Measures
sec.p: After they had responded to the online informed consent and agreed to continue, the respondents were then asked to complete the subsequent sections of the online survey. The second section of the survey contained seven demographic items. These items were used to collect data about each respondent’s age, gender, race/ethnicity, and SES (defined in terms of both parents’ education levels and total family income).

The next six sections of the survey contained the six personality measures (social desirability, impulsivity, aggression, conventional morality, ego defensiveness, and AIAF) that we used to predict the respondents’ scores on the RS, which appeared in the final (ninth) section of the online survey. A detailed description of each of these measures is provided below. All these measures were presented consecutively in a single session. The entire online survey consisted of 135 items, and this item count included the 10 RS items and the 7 demographic questions.4

sec.title: Shortened version of the Marlowe–Crowne Social Desirability Scale (SD)
sec.p: A short (10-item) version of the Marlowe–Crowne Social Desirability Scale (Crowne & Marlowe, 1960) was developed by Strahan and Gerbasi (1972) to gauge the tendency of an individual to answer questions in a socially desirable or undesirable manner. The 10 items on this measure were each rated on a 5-point Likert-type scale that ranged from 1 (extremely uncharacteristic of me) to 5 (extremely characteristic of me). The reliability (Cronbach’s alpha) of the measure in the current sample was .63. For validity information, see Strahan and Gerbasi (1972) and Fischer and Fick (1993).

sec.title: Impulsivity Scale (I)
sec.p: Four items from Schweinle, Ickes, Rollings, and Jacquot’s (2010) Temperament Scale were combined with five items from the Barratt Impulsiveness Scale Version 10 (Barratt, 1985) to create the 9-item measure of impulsivity that we used in the present study. Each item was rated on a 5-point Likert-type scale that ranged from 1 (completely disagree) to 5 (completely agree). The reliability coefficient of the measure in the current sample was .77; however, because we combined items from two previous measures, no validity data are available that are specific to this measure.

sec.title: Buss–Perry Aggression Questionnaire (AQ)
sec.p: The Aggression Questionnaire was developed by Buss and Perry (1992) to evaluate an individual’s level of dispositional aggression. This measure includes 29 items, each rated on a 5-point Likert-type scale that that ranged from 1 (completely disagree) to 5 (completely agree). The reliability coefficient in the current sample was .88. For information about the scale’s validity, see Buss and Perry (1992).

sec.title: Conventional Morality Scale (CM)
sec.p: The Conventional Morality Scale was developed by Tooke and Ickes (1988) to measure the extent to which a person adheres to the conventional moral values of the Judeo-Christian religious tradition. The item content for this scale was drawn from the Ten Commandments and the Seven Deadly Sins (for sample items, see Appendix B). However, to disguise the intent of the measure, all items were written as if they reflected individual lifestyle preferences, and the scale appeared on the survey under the label Lifestyle Preference Questionnaire (for more details about the scale’s construction and format, see Tooke & Ickes, 1988). The conventional morality measure contained 45 items, each rated on a 5-point Likert-type scale that that ranged from 1 (completely disagree) to 5 (completely agree). The measure’s reliability coefficient in the current sample was .90. For validity information, see Tooke and Ickes (1988) and Tooke (1988).

sec.title: Ego Defensiveness Scale (ED)
sec.p: The Ego Defensiveness Scale was developed by William Ickes and Anna Park. It assesses ego defensiveness by identifying the extent to which the respondents are “thin-skinned” individuals who refuse to accept criticism or correction from others (for sample items, see Appendix B). The 10 items on this measure were each rated on a 5-point Likert-type scale that ranged from 1 (completely disagree) to 5 (completely agree). The measure’s reliability coefficient in the current sample was .67. Because this is a new scale, the present article contains the only validity evidence for the ego defensiveness measure so far.

sec.title: Affect Intensity for Anger and Frustration (AIAF)
sec.p: The AIAF was developed by William Ickes and Anna Park to evaluate individual differences in one’s affect intensity while dealing with situations that evoke feelings of anger and frustration (for sample items, see Appendix B). This measure consisted of 15 items, each rated on a 6-point Likert-type scale that ranged from 1 (never) to 6 (always). The reliability coefficient in the current sample was .88. Because this is a new scale, the present article reports the only validity evidence for the AIAF to be obtained so far.

sec.title: Rudeness Scale (RS)
sec.p: The RS was developed by William Ickes to measure individual differences in the propensity to verbally abuse hypothetical strangers who threaten one’s status, power, or “face.” This measure includes 10 hypothetical situation items, each with four alternative responses that vary in their “rudeness points” (see Appendix A). The reliability of the RS in the current sample was .76. The present study is the first to use the RS; for that reason, it reports the only validity evidence to be obtained for this measure so far.

Because it was difficult to create plausible-sounding alternatives for each of the RS items that resulted in a clear-cut assignment of 1, 2, 3, or 4 “rudeness points,” data were collected from 12 graduate and undergraduate research assistants who rated the four alternatives for each RS item on a scale of 1 (least rude) to 4 (most rude). The intraclass correlation for the ratings made by these 12 judges was .94. The ratings indicated strong agreement regarding the alternatives that were assigned the “rudeness point” values of 1 and 4 for all 10 items. On the other hand, the ratings suggested that “rudeness point” values other than 2 and 3 should be assigned to the intermediate alternatives for items 3, 7, and 9. See Appendix A for the recommended “rudeness points” to assign when scoring each of the items on the RS.

sec.title: Intercorrelations of the Personality Measures and the Rudeness Measure
sec.p: The zero-order intercorrelations of the personality measures and the rudeness measures are reported in Table 1, along with those for the sociodemographic variables of gender and race. Because gender and race were categorical variables, it was necessary to recode them into a format suitable for correlation and regression. Weighted effects codes were used for both variables because this type of coding is optimal when, as in the current data set, there were unequal numbers of cases for each group. For gender, the simple bivariate correlations were examined for each personality variable. To obtain the zero-order correlations for race, however, required a more complex procedure that would account for each of the different racial groups. Four separate weighted effects codes were created for race and entered into a regression. The overall R for the model represented the zero-order correlation between the race variable as a whole and the outcome variable.

sec.p: For this series of correlational analyses, all six personality predictors were significantly correlated with the respondents’ total rudeness scores. The propensity for verbal rudeness was positively related to self-reported impulsivity (.25), aggression (.37), ego defensiveness (.38), and AIAF (.34). On the other hand, rudeness was negatively correlated with conventional morality (−.52) and social desirability (−.33). Finally, rudeness was related to being male as opposed to female (.14).5

sec.title: Assessing the Unique Contribution of the Predictors in Multiple Regression Analyses
Initial test of main effects
sec.p: Because the six personality predictors were themselves intercorrelated to a substantial degree (the significant zero-order correlations in Table 1 range from −.32 to .61), a multiple regression analysis was needed to assess each predictor’s unique contribution to scores on the rudeness measure when all other predictors were held constant. We also wanted to see if any of the demographic variables (gender, age, race, and SES) were unique predictors of rudeness. We therefore tested an initial “main effects only” regression model, which included each of the personality and demographic variables as potential predictors.

Once again, weighted effects codes were used for both the race and gender variables because they provide an estimate of the difference between each group and the overall weighted grand mean. This type of coding is optimal when, as in the current data set, there were unequal numbers of cases for each group. Following procedures suggested by Cohen, Cohen, West, and Aiken (2003), race/ethnicity was entered into the second “block” of the regression model as four weighted effects codes. All other variables were included in the first block of the regression model. It was necessary to place the four race codes in the second block of the model so that the change in R2 could be assessed. A significant change in R2 would indicate that there was a main effect for the race/ethnicity variable after controlling for the various personality effects.

The results of this initial “main effects only” model revealed that social desirability, impulsivity, and aggression were not significant as unique predictors of the respondents’ rudeness scores; nor were the demographic variables of gender, age, and SES. There were, however, significant effects for ego defensiveness, b = .18, t(262) = 3.24, p < .01, sr2 = .02, conventional morality, b = −.39, t(262) = −5.97, p < .001, sr2 = .09, and AIAF, b = .10, t(262) = 2.24, p < .05, sr2 = .01, as well as a slight but statistically significant effect for race/ethnicity, ΔR2 = .03, ΔF(4, 261) = 2.82, p < .05.

sec.title: Test of interactions
sec.p: The results of the “main effects only” model suggested that we could delete many of the potential predictors (in particular, gender, age, SES, impulsivity, and aggression) from the regression model. However, to make sure that none of these candidate-for-deletion variables were implicated in significant higher order interaction effects, we conducted a second multiple regression analysis that included all of the first-order terms as well as all possible two-way and three-way interaction terms. The results of this analysis revealed no significant two- or three-way interaction effects, an outcome that enabled us to test the final, “main effects only” model that we describe below.

sec.title: Final test of main effects
sec.p: In our final regression analysis, we obtained the parameter estimates for a model that included only those predictors that were significant in the initial main effects model. Social desirability was also included in this model, however, even though it was not a significant predictor in the preliminary regression analysis, because it is widely considered to be an important control variable (i.e., covariate). As before, we used a sequential regression analysis to test the effect of the race/ethnicity variable in the second block of the model, with the four personality variables tested in the model’s first block of predictors.

This simplified main effects model accounted for a combined 35% of the total variance in the participants’ rudeness scores. With regard to the personality predictors, conventional morality was the strongest predictor of rudeness. It accounted for more than twice as much unique variance as either of the other significant predictors: ego-defensiveness and AIAF. Table 2 displays the parameter estimates for these effects.

sec.p: Adding the race codes in the second “block” of the model again resulted in a significant unique contribution to the prediction of rudeness scores, ΔR2 = .03, ΔF(4, 265) = 2.61, p < .05. Probing this main effect involved using dummy codes and running separate regression models so that each racial group could be treated as the comparison against which all other races were compared (Aiken & West, 1991; Cohen et al., 2003). The results revealed that Hispanics/Latinos scored significantly higher in their rudeness propensity than both Asians, b = .24, t(252) = 3.14, p < .01, and Whites, b = .15, t(252) = 2.41, p < .05. Blacks scored significantly higher on rudeness than Asians, b = .20, t(252) = 2.42, p < .05 but not than Whites. No other comparisons were significantly different.

In summary, the present findings revealed that the people who are most likely to verbally abuse strangers are those who are Latino or Black and who score low on the measures of conventional morality but high on ego defensiveness and AIAF. After controlling for the contributions of these variables, there were no effects for the remaining demographic variables (gender, age, SES) or the remaining personality variables (social desirability, impulsivity, or aggression).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In an online survey study (n = 275), we used several demographic and personality variables to predict scores on the RS, a new measure of the propensity to verbally abuse strangers. The results of a series of multiple regression analyses revealed a number of additive main effects. These effects indicated that the persons in our sample who reported the greatest propensity to verbally abuse strangers were Hispanic/Latino or Black individuals who scored low in their adherence to the standards of conventional morality but high in ego defensiveness (unwillingness to accept criticism or correction from others) and AIAF. Once the effects of these defining variables were accounted for, there were no significant residual effects for the variables of gender, age, SES, social desirability, impulsivity, or aggression/hostility.

sec.title: Interpretation of the Findings
sec.p: Our interpretation of these findings combines insights derived from Swann and Read (1981); Swann (1983, 1999) self-verification theory, contrasting views of ego defensiveness, and Larsen, Diener, and Emmons’s (1986) work on affect intensity with a dispositional view of verbal rudeness that emphasizes its use as a weapon in interpersonal struggles for power, status, and “face.” We will introduce these insights successively, beginning with our interpretation of the effect for the strongest predictor of verbal rudeness—the respondents’ scores on Tooke and Ickes’s (1988) measure of adherence to conventional morality.

sec.title: (Low) adherence to conventional morality
sec.p: The fundamental tenet of Swann and Read (1981); Swann (1983, 1999) self-verification theory is that people have a strong motive to maintain a consistent view of themselves; and, in the service of that motive, will forcefully defend their self-image when it is challenged or threatened by other people. Swann further asserts that this motive applies even to people whose self-images might be regarded as “negative” by others, for example, people who are depressed (Swann, Wenzlaff, Krull, & Pelham, 1992), people with low self-esteem (Swann, Chang-Schneider, & McClarty, 2007), and people who pride themselves on their outlaw image and believe that “it’s good to be bad.”

We suggest that Swann and Read (1981); Swann (1983, 1999) self-verification motive is the one that accounts for the strong link in the present study between the respondents’ (low) scores on the Conventional Morality Scale and their (high) scores on the RS. For people who reject the standards of conventional morality (i.e., those who ignore many or all the Ten Commandments and indulge in many or all of the Seven Deadly Sins), it is a rude affront to their own self-image to be accosted by a total stranger and informed that their current behavior fails to measure up to one or more of those standards. When low–conventional morality individuals respond to such a challenge by saying “I think you’re confusing me with someone who gives a shit about your bullshit rules,” they undoubtedly mean what they say. In their view, the challenger has criticized them without knowing who they are or what they stand for. Because they don’t accept the standards of conventional morality, they may feel perfectly justified in viewing the other person as the rude offender, rather than themselves, and in countering his or her rude act with a blast of verbal rudeness that is intended to send a loud and clear message: “I’m not who you seem to think I am. So fuck off!”

sec.title: (High) ego defensiveness
sec.p: A factor that further elevates the low–conventional morality person’s tendency to verbally abuse strangers in response to a perceived challenge or criticism is a high level of ego defensiveness, which we define as a “thin-skinned” refusal to accept criticism or correction from others. Our interpersonal definition of ego defensiveness differs from Carl Rogers’s (1961) more intrapersonal one. As a practicing psychotherapist, Rogers (1961) was primarily interested in how people defend their egos internally, by using defense mechanisms such as denial, distortion, and subception (“tuning out”) as a way of avoiding, ignoring, or minimizing threatening feedback from others. In contrast, our Ego Defensiveness Scale places a primary emphasis on how people defend their egos externally, by immediately and forcefully rejecting any actual or implied criticism from others. When this tendency (high ego defensiveness) is combined with a personal rejection of the standards of conventional morality (low conventional morality), the result is a personality that is especially likely to take offense at being criticized for ignoring moral or ethical standards that he or she does not even endorse—including the one about not directing verbal abuse at a stranger.

sec.title: (High) AIAF
sec.p: A second factor that further elevates the low–conventional morality person’s tendency to verbally abuse strangers is a high level of AIAF. The desire to verbally abuse others is often checked by considerations of self-interest (e.g., fear of retaliation, being perceived by others as unable to “keep your cool”). However, when one is temperamentally predisposed to overreact to situations that elicit feelings of anger and frustration, “keeping your cool” may simply not be an option. As Larsen et al. (1986) have noted, affect intensity may be the crucial variable that separates people who restrain themselves in such situations from those who lash out at others instead.6

sec.title: The dispositionally rude person
sec.p: These three factors—low adherence to conventional morality, high ego defensiveness in the form of rejecting any criticism or correction from others, and high AIAF—may prove to be key elements in the personality of the dispositionally rude person. For rudeness to become dispositional, however, it has to become both habitual and frequently reinforced. And on this point Smith et al.’s (2010) Australian data are highly relevant, because they indicate that when people are verbally abused by someone whose manners they hoped to correct, their typical reaction is to just “leave the situation or to let it drop” (p. 197).

Whenever this happens, the verbally abusive person gets rewarded in at least two ways. First, by using in-your-face rudeness to reject the other person’s challenge or criticism, the verbally abusive person successfully defends his or her self-image as someone who “doesn’t give a shit” about the social conventions on which the challenger has based his or her claim. Second, by using in-your-face rudeness to catch the other person off guard, the verbally abusive person can escalate the tension in the encounter so dramatically and unexpectedly that the other person typically shuts up, backs down, and slinks away, thereby allowing the verbally abusive person to win the implicit competition for power, status, and “face.” Given such immediate, reliable, and powerful reinforcement for individual acts of verbal rudeness, it is easy to see how verbal abusiveness becomes first a habit and then a firmly entrenched disposition. The result is one more dispositionally rude person for the rest of the world to have to deal with.

sec.title: Is race/ethnicity important?
sec.p: Is race/ethnicity an important variable in the study of social rudeness? Although it did not emerge as important in Smith et al.’s (2010) Australian study, there was evidence in the present study that Latinos and Blacks (of both genders) may have a greater propensity for verbal rudeness than Whites and Asians. We have two observations to make in this regard. First, Asians tend to represent cultural traditions in which harmony is emphasized and a premium is placed on being (at least outwardly) polite and respectful of others. Second, Latinos and Blacks, as members of the two largest racial minority groups in the United States, have a history of being regarded as “second-class citizens” who may have learned to counter this stereotype by being vocal and assertive rather than polite and circumspect, as most Asians seem to be. Although our study appears to provide the first direct evidence that race/ethnicity may be an important variable in the study of rudeness, future researchers would be well advised to test for the effects of this variable as well.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations of the Present Investigation
sec.p: Although the present study appears to shed some light on the propensity to verbally abuse others, its strengths are qualified by some noteworthy limitations. The study’s strengths include its substantial sample size, its investigation of both demographic and personality predictors, and the reasonably clear-cut main effect findings that emerged. In addition, the study controlled for social desirability response bias in identifying three predictors (low conventional morality, high ego defensiveness, and high AIAF) that seem to capture essential aspects of the personality of the dispositionally rude person, while at the same time identifying two other predictors (impulsivity, anger/hostility) that appear to contribute nothing else that is essential in this regard.

On the other hand, the study’s college student sample, though relatively large, is not sufficiently heterogeneous with regard to the age and SES variables—a limitation that might account for the lack of significant effects for these demographic predictors in the present investigation. In addition, our sample lacks geographical diversity as well. Finally, although we had some success predicting the self-reported propensity to verbally abuse strangers, we cannot simply assume that our predictors will predict actual acts of verbal rudeness in addition to hypothetical ones. Still, given the formidable difficulties of studying rudeness in situ that Smith et al. (2010) have noted, the present study makes a useful contribution by providing an alternative methodology and a new set of findings that may help to inform our understanding of this interesting but understudied phenomenon.

sec.title: Directions for Future Research
sec.p: There are a number of interesting directions for future research. First, the present study focused on personality variables that might facilitate verbal rudeness; future research should also examine personality variables (such as scores on inhibition and self-control measures) that could inhibit or restrain verbal rudeness. Second, future research should be conducted with more diverse and heterogeneous samples, as noted above. Third, future research should change the role of the RS from an outcome variable to a predictor variable, and test to see whether scores on the RS can successfully predict actual rude behavior, both in the laboratory and in real-world settings. For example, are new telemarketers who score higher on the RS more likely to give offense and be hung up on by potential customers than are their lower scoring counterparts? These are just a few of the many directions that researchers could pursue in their attempts to dissect the fascinating phenomenon of verbal rudeness in everyday life.

sec.title: Rudeness Scale
sec.p: Please read each of the following items and then choose the alternative that best describes how you would respond if you were in the situation described. Different people would react in different ways, so please be honest about what your own reactions would be in the following situations.

list-item.p: 1. You are watching a movie with a friend in a crowded movie theater. You make a funny comment to your friend about what just happened onscreen, and a woman who is sitting behind you says “Be quiet during the film!” Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would apologize to her and stop talking during the movie. (1)*
b. I would ignore her and keep talking out loud to my friend. (3)
c. I would whisper to my friend about what a bitch she was. (2)
d. I would turn to her and say “Why don’t you shut the fuck up?” (4)

2. You are window shopping in a large enclosed shopping mall when a strange man comes rushing past you from behind and clips you hard on the shoulder as he brushes past. Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would say, “Look where you’re going, asshole!” (4)
b. I would say, “Hey, you owe me an apology!” (2)
c. I would say, “Hey, are you blind or something?” (3)
d. I wouldn’t say anything, but I’d think he was a jerk. (1)

3. You go out to eat and take the last available parking spot. When you come back out after finishing your meal, a man is standing by your car who chastises you for parking in a space marked “Handicapped Drivers Only.” Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would tell him to fuck off. (4)
b. I would ignore him completely. (2.5)
c. I would tell him to mind his own business. (2.5)
d. I would apologize to him. (1)

4. You are at a public event wearing a T-shirt with a slogan that some people might find offensive. A woman with two small children comes up to you and tells you that you shouldn’t be wearing that shirt at “a family-oriented event.” Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would make no response whatsoever. (2)
b. I would apologize to her. (1)
c. I would tell her that she’s the one who’s being offensive. (3)
d. I would tell her to fuck off and leave me alone. (4)

5. Not noticing a trash receptacle near the exit to the fast-food restaurant, you open the car door and set the trash in your fast-food bag down on the curb. A store employee sees you do this, points to the trash receptacle, and tells you to put it there. Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would apologize and do what he said. (1)
b. I would say, “I’ll tell you where you can put it.” (4)
c. I would give him a dirty look and then drive off. (3)
d. I would pretend that I didn’t hear him. (2)

6. You are sitting in a coffee shop, talking on your cell phone to a friend. When your friend tells you about something really bad that just happened, you say “Fuck! I can’t believe it! That is really fucked up!” At that point, one of the customers―an elderly lady―tells you to “Watch your language!” Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would tune her out and keep talking to my friend. (3)
b. I would interrupt the phone conversation to apologize to her. (1)
c. I would tell her that my phone call is none of her fucking business. (4)
d. I would step outside and finish my phone conversation there. (2)

7. You are sitting on a crowded bus when a well-dressed woman with multiple shopping bags gets on and stands in the aisle next to your seat. She asks if you would be willing to change places with her. Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would readily agree to her request. (1)
b. I would tell her to fuck off. (4)
c. I would shake my head in refusal. (2.75)
d. I would tell her she can have the seat when I leave. (2.25)

8. You have just gotten a very bad haircut and are leaving the shop feeling very self-conscious. As you are walking to your car, a small boy points you out to one of his friends and says “Look at that stupid haircut!” Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would agree with the kid that it was a stupid haircut. (1)
b. I would tell the kid to fuck off while he still had the chance. (4)
c. I would tell the kid that my haircut wasn’t any stupider than his. (3)
d. I would ignore the kid and pretend that I didn’t hear him. (2)

9. You are crossing a busy intersection on foot when the light changes to red, so the line of cars to your right have to wait several extra seconds for you before they can proceed. The driver in first car, a middle-aged man, rolls down his window and tells you to “Pay attention to the traffic light!” Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would refuse to look at him and act like I didn’t hear. (2.25)
b. I would say “Sorry about that!” and walk a bit faster. (1)
c. I would give him the finger, along with a dirty look. (4)
d. I would lift my hands and shrug, but not say anything. (2.75)

10. You are driving in a shopping mall parking lot, looking for an empty parking space. A woman is driving toward you from the opposite direction with her left-turn indicator blinking. When you see an empty parking space on your right and pull into it, the woman rolls down her window and says “That’s my space; I was signaling to turn in there!” Which of the following would be your most likely response?
a. I would say, “Too bad, but I got here first.” (3)
b. I would say, “Fuck you, it’s my space now.” (4)
c. I would say, “I’m sorry, let me back up so you can have it.” (1)
d. I would park the car and walk off without saying anything. (2)

sec.p: *The numbers in parentheses are the “rudeness points” for each of the alternatives for a given item.

sec.title: Sample Items from The Conventional Morality Scale, Ego Defensiveness Scale, and Affect Intensity for Aggression and Frustration Scale
sec.p: Conventional Morality Scale (Lifestyle Preference Questionnaire; 45 items)

list-item.p: I would not steal something I needed, even if I were sure I could get away with it.
I “tune out” most of what my parents say to me.
I could not kill another person under any circumstances.
If I had enough money, I wouldn’t work another day.
I don’t enjoy looking at pornographic films or magazines.
I envy people who have more than I do.

sec.p: Ego Defensiveness Scale (10 items)

list-item.p: I don’t tolerate having to take a lot of criticism from other people.
Too many people try to blame me for things that simply aren’t my fault.
I appreciate it when people call my attention to things I’m doing wrong.
Most of what other people call “constructive criticism” I don’t find helpful at all.

sec.p: Affect Intensity for Anger and Frustration (15 items)

list-item.p: I get so frustrated in traffic that I have to hit the horn or pound on the wheel.
When I get angry, the feeling becomes so intense that it takes me a long time to calm down.
I react to day-to-day frustrations in ways that other people consider extreme.
My feelings of anger are more intense than those of most other people.

It would be better, of course, to study these reactions in real-life encounters. However, as Smith et al. (2010) have noted, these kinds of incidents are so rare and so fleeting in everyday life that the practical difficulties of capturing them in situ are simply daunting.

In correlations not involving the rudeness measure, gender was also associated with aggression and adherence to conventional morality, such that females scored lower on aggression but higher on conventional morality than males. Race was significantly associated with aggression and affect intensity. Probing these last two correlations involved using dummy codes and running separate regression models so that each racial group could be treated as the comparison against which all other races were compared (Aiken & West, 1991; Cohen et al., 2003). The results of these separate models revealed that Asians scored significantly higher on affect intensity than both Whites, b = .37, t(265) = 3.11, p < .01, sr2 = .03 and Hispanics, b = .22, t(265) = 2.34, p < .05, sr2 = .02. Blacks also scored significantly higher on affect intensity than Whites, b = .29, t(265) = 2.45, p < .05, sr2 = .02. There were no other comparisons that were significantly different for affect intensity. Blacks scored significantly higher on aggression than Whites, b = .23, t(265) = 2.49, p < .05, sr2 = .02, and Hispanics, b = .31, t(265) = 3.04, p < .01, sr2 = .03, but there were no other comparisons that were significantly different for aggression.

Interestingly, although we originally intended to use Larsen et al.’s (1986) Affect Intensity Measure (AIM) as one of the personality predictors in this study, a close examination of the AIM’s item content revealed that it contained almost no items that assessed affect intensity for anger and/or frustration (AIAF). Our inability to find a targeted measure of this type in a search of the PsychInfo database led us to develop our own measure, the AIAF Scale.
